text: <@U6A0PD8CR> thanks for your dagger ml presentation. I had to leave early, but is the idea that even in models with a  serial dependency structure you can just start a new forward pass as long as the first gpu is cleared ?

elements.text: thanks for your dagger ml presentation. I had to leave early, but is the idea that even in models with a  serial dependency structure you can just start a new forward pass as long as the first gpu is cleared ?

text: That wasn't the point I made, but that is still potentially possible if you express batching within the DAG.

elements.text: That wasn't the point I made, but that is still potentially possible if you express batching within the DAG.

text: The point is, if you have operations which are independent of each other, then make them independent "thunks" in the DAG, and Dagger will figure out the rest.

elements.text: The point is, if you have operations which are independent of each other, then make them independent "thunks" in the DAG, and Dagger will figure out the rest.

text: Also, if you do the model instantiation with Dagger, you get heterogeneous execution "for free", since Dagger knows about multithreading, CUDA GPUs, and AMD GPUs, and will use them freely if you let it.

elements.text: Also, if you do the model instantiation with Dagger, you get heterogeneous execution "for free", since Dagger knows about multithreading, CUDA GPUs, and AMD GPUs, and will use them freely if you let it.
